CivExamSim.fact: A Delaware company with no offices or employees in Texas sells 5% of its products online to Texas residents.
CivExamSim.rule: Daimler AG v. Bauman — sporadic sales insufficient for general jurisdiction; not 'essentially at home.'

CivExamSim.fact: A Florida driver crashes into a Georgia resident while driving through Georgia.
CivExamSim.rule: International Shoe — claim arises out of defendant’s in-state conduct; specific jurisdiction proper.

CivExamSim.fact: An Ohio tire explodes in France, injuring a French driver; the tire was originally sold in Ohio.
CivExamSim.rule: Goodyear v. Brown — no general jurisdiction over foreign subsidiaries; claim unrelated to forum contacts.

CivExamSim.fact: A Pennsylvania plaintiff sues a Virginia manufacturer for injuries from a product purchased in Virginia but used in Pennsylvania.
CivExamSim.rule: Bristol-Myers Squibb — claim must arise out of or relate to defendant’s forum contacts.

CivExamSim.fact: A New York newspaper posts an online article allegedly defaming a Texas resident.
CivExamSim.rule: Calder v. Jones — jurisdiction proper only if defendant’s conduct expressly aimed at forum; passive site insufficient.

CivExamSim.fact: A California car dealer advertises online; a Colorado buyer travels to California, buys a car, and crashes in Colorado.
CivExamSim.rule: World-Wide Volkswagen — unilateral action by consumer cannot create forum contacts.

CivExamSim.fact: A Nevada casino mails flyers and offers free rooms to California residents who later sue in California for injuries at the casino.
CivExamSim.rule: Kulko / Walden v. Fiore — contact must arise from defendant’s purposeful forum conduct, not plaintiff’s connections.

CivExamSim.fact: A corporate officer personally guarantees a loan in Texas and later disputes the contract.
CivExamSim.rule: Burger King v. Rudzewicz — purposeful availment through deliberate contract negotiation with forum resident.

CivExamSim.fact: A Minnesota company registers to do business in Pennsylvania and appoints a local agent for service.
CivExamSim.rule: Mallory v. Norfolk Southern — registration statute can constitute consent to general jurisdiction.

CivExamSim.fact: A New Jersey car dealer sells through a regional distributor who sells into Louisiana; a Louisiana buyer is injured.
CivExamSim.rule: Stream of Commerce — jurisdiction proper if defendant purposefully directed products into forum market.

CivExamSim.fact: A Georgia corporation has continuous offices and staff in Alabama but is sued there for a Kentucky accident.
CivExamSim.rule: Perkins v. Benguet Mining — continuous and systematic contacts justify general jurisdiction.

CivExamSim.fact: A Texas court hears a divorce case though neither spouse lives in Texas.
CivExamSim.rule: Courts must have authority over type of case; residency required for domestic relations.

CivExamSim.fact: A Mississippi plaintiff sues a Japanese manufacturer in Mississippi for injuries caused by a product sold there by a regional distributor.
CivExamSim.rule: Asahi / Nicastro — split views; must show targeting of forum, not mere foreseeability.

CivExamSim.fact: A Kansas company sues a Colorado buyer in Kansas federal court for breach of contract.
CivExamSim.rule: 28 U.S.C. §1332 — diversity of citizenship and >$75,000 in controversy confer subject-matter jurisdiction.

CivExamSim.fact: A plaintiff files a federal civil rights claim under 42 U.S.C. §1983 against a state officer.
CivExamSim.rule: 28 U.S.C. §1331 — cases arising under federal law create federal question jurisdiction.

CivExamSim.fact: A federal court hears a state-law negligence claim appended to a federal employment discrimination case.
CivExamSim.rule: §1367 — supplemental jurisdiction when claims share common nucleus of operative fact.

CivExamSim.fact: A plaintiff sues in federal court over a $60,000 contract dispute between citizens of different states.
CivExamSim.rule: §1332 requires >$75,000; amount-in-controversy not met.

CivExamSim.fact: A plaintiff sues an in-state defendant in federal court for negligence under state law only.
CivExamSim.rule: No diversity (same state) and no federal question; case must be filed in state court.

CivExamSim.fact: A corporation incorporated in Delaware but headquartered in California is sued in both states.
CivExamSim.rule: Daimler — 'at home' in both state of incorporation and principal place of business.

CivExamSim.fact: A federal court transfers a case for convenience to another district where it could have been brought.
CivExamSim.rule: 28 U.S.C. §1404(a) — transfer for convenience when both venue and jurisdiction proper.
